Java uses the "extends" keyword to set the relationship between a child class and a parent class. Here, MountainBike is the child class and Bicycle is the parent class. MountainBike class inherits all the properties of the Bicycle class.

Bird class is a child class (a subclass) of class Animal.

Subclasses can override methods of their superclass to provide their own implementation of a particular piece of functionality. The overriding method should have the same signature (return type, method name, list of parameters), as does the overridden method.Now objects of class Bird and objects of a more general class Animal will behave differently when reporting their moveMethod()

The Coffee class is declared and extends the parent class Liquid.  The extends keyword shows a relationship between the child class Coffee and parent class Liquid.
Coffee will override the swirl method.  If the method did not override this method, no declaration would be needed and Coffee could use swirl method as written in parent class Liquid.
The actual override part of the method, a different statement is sent to the output.  Instead of  "Swirling Liquid" from the parent class, "Swirling Coffee" is sent to the output.
The Milk class is declared and extends the parent class Liquid.  The extends keyword shows a relationship between the child class Milk and parent class Liquid.
Milk will override the swirl method.  If the method did not override this method, no declaration would be needed and Milk could use swirl method as written in parent class Liquid.
The actual changed part of the overridden method.  A different phrase is sent to the output.

A variable declaration statement always contains a data type, a variable name and a semicolon. This statement declares an integer variable 'i'.

Type of the variable identifies the kind of data that can be stored in this variable. Type 'String' is used to declare variables holding strings (text 
sequences).
You can declare several variables of the same type in one statement. Variable names should be separated with a comma. This statement declares two integer variables 'a' and 'b'.

Variable initialization is used to declare a variable and immediately assign 
an initial value to it. This statement declares an integer variable named 'i'

nothing happens for the unmatched cases.

Declares a variable named 'width' and initializes(assigns) it with integer 10.
The console output is: 10
Changes width to 20 (assigns 20 to width).
So far, the console output has two lines. The first line is 1020. After printing 20, the cursor moves to the new line (with empty string).
The right hand side of an assignment can be an expression. Now width is assigned 30.
The console output has three lines now. The first line is 1020, the second line is 30, and the third line is just empty string.

The same variable can occur on both sides of an assignment. In this case, the right side width represents the older value of width (30). We first conduct operations on the right side, and then assigns the result of 30+10 to the width on the left side. So the left side width represents the final value of width, which is 40.
